Alright man, You still have addressed, fundamentally, why it isn't good for a hero to do everything and how that overshadows when drafting other picks.
You make good points, they just don't really justify having one mage picked over the other two constantly. It was just like KT when he was in the position ming was. You could pick him to cover all these things and no one else ever got picked. Plus you always had decent waveclear with Ming with a good orb placed to the side of the wave.
I'd bet she's still picked over the other two the majority of the time but instead of 9/10 times or 10/10 it's closer to 6/10 or 7/10 times.
And that's where we'll disagree, it isn't good design having heroes do everything. Absolutely not. And no they didn't lose KT's waveclear, they nerfed his single target blow up potential.
She's not randomly gimped and this is the core of what people are getting at. You could always waveclear with a well placed orb.

e r that's what makes heroes unique in HotS. On the same note some heroes are going to be similar i ncertain ways. Particularly when it comes to draft. You're going to draft one of those three KT, Jaina, o r Ming. So you do need to make the comparable in a sense. If one of them does everything better than all of them, there's no decision on who to pick. Currently that's the case. When we pick a mage Ranged carry mage we pick ming over KT or jaina, almost everytime.

i find it hard to imagine people are pushing back against the calamity change. her wave clear puts her in the same spot as KT was when he was OP OP.
And what is it exactly? You don't want heroes taht can do it all. They can't check all the boxes. Good hero dmg, good team fight, ranged burst carry, good laning/rotations, good poke, wave clear. It covers too many bases, especially with the nature of draft.
So of all those things they could have changed with calamity they removed part of her pve and wave clear. It could have been reduction in damage overall and talented into 150% vs minions on calamity.
Mcintyre in his review of the patch notes, rather the PTR patch notes, on noting Tyrael's santification nerf from 80 sec to 100 and Li Ming's calamity nerf said they shouldnt be nerfing these heroes but buffing other heroes.
Now there's a point to that, to an extent. If we buff Jaina and KT to match Ming, they both have super short cd's. KT would be the problem he was. Nor would they feel as unique. Tyrael's nerf is trying to keep sanctification on a similar or slightly longer cd than a lot other heroics, powerful ones. So this prevents the dynamic of having Sanc ready to go every time without concern.
On the other hand Diablo, Artanis, and a few others did get buffs. There's a give and take. You don't want a hero, in draft, to satisfy all the marks. It's what makes a hero OP, competitively. At least dominant. And it shows in her pick rate.
as for your direct question, their cd's are much higher. And they're more balanced. Feel like people forget how powerful KT was back then. Should we go back to that? Like this isn't...Ming is picked primarily for her teamfight and reset potential. And that's what she should be focused on. You're talenting into the wave clear as much as you're talenting into a finisher for her combo, so that's kind of a weak argument. Whenever there's the option for a mage between ming, kt, and jaina you take ming everytime. Because she checks all those boxes.
Overall I'm just shocked people are even arguing this. She's still going to be a teamfight animal. Still can reset through a whole team and be ridiculously strong.

I actualyl was going to pitch an article to somewhere, and if you wanted to follow up with a part 2, it'd probably appropriate. Not sure if it's yours or an editorial call, regardless.
I think a large part of it is $$ and lack thereof in a young, growing scene.
That said, the role of a coach in HotS is even more critical. That's due in part to a combination of things. It comes mostly down to the fast paced nature of the game, combined and driving, the nature of shotcalling in HotS. Being in game can cloud your judgment, either with a tunnel vision, short nearsightedness, or too long a view.
Shotcalling is what differentiates HotS really. Despite what some people have said, without ever making a clear argument against it (or for similarities in other games), there's rarely a 100% correct thing to do in HotS. Whether it's choosing to take the obj, both obj's, push structures then obj, take a camp, invade a camp or something simpler, is this the fight we take? is it the fight we have to take?
Granted, we all see this, at least those with a keen eye, in our everyday games without recourse. On the pro level, it is everything though. While your shotcaller fulfills this role in game, in training having someone outside the game to help guide that decision making will help in training you to be a better shotcaller in tournament matches.
A good example was a game from...the summer championship where one team, on Sky Temple, went Tyrael/Morales/Raynor cheese. They got the keep and the team who was at risk of being cored took the wipe opportunity, all ~30ish seconds of it to boss. Then hearth back, defend, the core was knocked to 60% and proceeded to base race. The added damage from the boss, the boss taking the keep(!), and the pressure it created, the decision as a whole was critical to winning the game against the cheese. Their window to do that was minuscule at best and the risk was great.
Watching top tier abathur play shows it too. At what point he goes from soaking/clearing a lane to hopping in and committing to the 5 man team fight with evolution. These are simpler but more relatable examples for the average viewer. The more games I watch as a caster though, related the decisions I thought and think a team is going to do, vs what they, arguably, should do and what they ultimately do, predicted or not and for better or worst have really brought this point to fruition. As the meta evolves alongside the dynamic map pool this hand in hand will continue to drive HotS as a shotcalling or coaches game.
Now as for whether the coaches are allowed on comms is another discussion. Some places I think allowed it during their last season (Korea, iirc?). The fact that this has already been broached, granted in a region that values coaches, is telling. Korea being the top region, also strengthens the point of HotS being a coaches/shotcallers game.
Often people make comparisons to other sports. The top comment here even does on the importance of coaching. There's a saying that defense wins championships and coaches build legacies. I don't think it's any coincidence the first legacy of HotS was MVP Black's 40+ game win streak nor is the Korean region's dominance accidental. The nature of HotS as a coaches game adds to that resolve. A final note is to examine the speed and efficiency KR teams make their in game decisions and commit to them. Rarely is there a moment that they are 'deciding' what to do and never does a caster suggest they aren't sure.
This resolve and unity alone, can give them the edge to win even when making the wrong decisions. It certainly speaks to the strength of good coaching which in turn imparts the shotcaller with excellent, quick, decisive, judgment.
Anywho, that's my two cents. Sorry I'm tight for time, casting Heroes Hype tonight 9PM EST at twitch.tv/Heroes_hype with /u/halorin (@ (lol self plug! tweet it out!),

Yeah, in light of that the HGC set up I think is really positive. It opens up competition directly between pro-am teams and pro.
I cast and I casted a match...I can't recall what it was for but it was a sort of amateur championship that had a couple pro/semi pro teams on their way to regionals using it as warm up I think. Totally allowed to be there and everything though, they weren't like pro pro yet.
Anyway, they went up against what was, at the time, and it was a little bit ago so people weren't as good as they are now, a top NA amateur team. The ammy team got crushed and the skill gap was so apparent. Not totally crushed for a best of three but it was one sided for the two matches.
So, hopefully there will be solid communication now and door's opening for these guys to scrim and stuff, and rotate into the HGC.
That said, on top of the 5v5 teamwork, and what role the inhibit within it, flex, carry, support, tank, pseudo support, bruiser, melee plays a factor into it. And many pros can do all those roles on the HL/casual level.
Most importantly I think. And this is really where things get brought a step up, the way they look at the game and it comes together is just...different. It's super impressive watching them see things develop and adapt and overcome them, punish, capitalize or correct themselves on in the fast paced nature of HotS. That's really where, imo, pro's become a step up on everyone else.

They made the correct ruling for sure here. That said, the zera thing is banned now that we know about it because they aren't sure. So in that situation, when you're not sure you have to rule on the side of caution, allow it for the situation it was used in and then ban it from future use now that you know about it.

to be fair it's built from a game where this might not be an issue. sc2. Also, as a game designer, this just wouldn't be something I anticipated. Granted, in a more globalized world it's definitely a convenience but, from the jump, not something I'd consider a priority.
That's not to say, especially that there's demand, that it's something we shouldn't have. Just that being how the game was developed and in light of the circumstances, I can understand why it'd seem like a big hurdle. And, consequently, while there is demand, it's very possible that it's a vocal but small minority of demand. Probably very small.

nah im playen man. they're two higher skill cap heroes, well after illidan's changes maybe not. But you got to learn when to get in with Illidan, do some damage, and get out before you take any at the beginning of fights. Then learn when the team is low enough for you to really commit do damage, pop your ult, and go to town.
Tyrande, you need to learn her combo, which is hard, Hunter's Mark, Owl, Stun or vice versa. It does pretty decent damage. Learn to hit her stun foremost. Remember if you're marking for your team do it when DPS is around or on what they're attacking.
Tyrande will teach you to have good map awareness because you should be constantly throwing your owl out for vision to find the enemy team.

WRITING.TITLE: LPT: You can make a wrist pad to use at your computer out of a t-shirt or dish towels. Plus you can wash it too!
WRITING.TEXT:
We all know using padding for our wrists at the computer can help alleviate some of the stress and pressure that's put onto the nerves when leaning on the desk to type or use the mouse.
I bought a pad for my mouse and keyboard, One wore out over time, got surprisingly dirty, and was retired (the rogue coffee drop and one semi spill) and the other ended up with a couple holes from wear and tear (and beads! beads everywhere!). I kept forgetting to buy a new one when I was at Staples/order it online. I'm young and haven't had any pain or anything. While I do find them comfortable I guess I didn't prioritize it enough but it is something I want for my wrists.
I originally made one out of 3-4 ~~fish~~ dish towels, 6 x 6 or 6 x 8 inches (what? you don't know what a fish towel is?!? *jeez*). I laid them on top of one another and rolled/folded them. Sometimes they required rubber bands on one end or both ends to stay rolled and neat. You def could use glue too I guess, especially if it's going to be permanent. I also figured out (aka was painfully obvious) you could wash these if you did spill something (Dog's ambitious hop to my lap knocked a cup over).
I also learned you could use a t-shirt. My rag contaption lasted a while. It's end was still a bit premature but they worked great. Were soft, washable, I could use them as rags if I had to.
I needed something new though. Their eventful end (lol...working late, and tired led to an interesting end for them) found me in need of a new one.
So I did the same thing with a white undershirt that had a stain and was put to the side to become a rag. I took another one that was a little small on me athe moment too.
For the keyboard pad I did cut off the sleeves and the collar so it wasn't so lumpy but play around with it as much or little as you need. Fold it wide/roll it up, throw a rubber band on each end and there you go. Depending on how you fold it you can even make it shorter to for only one wrist if you were gaming and needed space for something else ( I have a bluetooth keyboard also for when I stream and a chromebook nearby too).
Anyway, they make for good makeshift on the spot solution until I get to the store to buy one.
